intro: Aethusa cynapium var. sylvestris, commonly known as the wild hemlock, is a biennial or short-lived perennial plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic foliage and umbellate inflorescences. The plant has finely divided, fern-like leaves and produces small, white flowers arranged in umbrella-shaped clusters. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. However, it is toxic and contains compounds that can be harmful to humans and animals.
